reasoning: The critique targets a moderately central aspect of the essay: the promised separation between “target size” (easy eutopia) and “navigation” (moral convergence/optimization), and the claim that the essay is mainly addressing (1). If correct, this would significantly weaken what the essay establishes on its own and shift weight to the sequel—but it would not fully collapse the broader “no easy eutopia” conclusion, which can be supported by other parts (e.g., Section 3’s taxonomy of value functions and fussiness). The critique has some real bite because many Section 2.3 examples are indeed about contingent future choice, moral disagreement, and governance failures—naturally classed as navigation problems. However, it somewhat overstates the misfit: the essay’s notion of “target size” is defined relative to the distribution of default futures absent deliberate de dicto optimization, and “many dimensions where a single flaw ruins value” can legitimately be construed as making the near-best set measure-small in outcome-space, not merely as crews aiming wrong. So it weakens the essay’s framing/partition more than it refutes the underlying argument. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little to no dead weight.
title: The evidence for a narrow target actually describes navigation failures
